article.title: Converting greenhouse gases into valuable liquid chemicals
article.teaser: With the support of EU funding, researchers are designing more efficient and economical processes for converting natural gas and carbon dioxide into high-value chemicals.

section.sectionBody:
Today, most people are well aware of the fact that CO2 causes climate change. However, many are unaware about another, even more potent form of greenhouse gas: natural gas, or CH4.
â€œWith natural gas production on the rise, there is an increasing need to simultaneously address both CO2 and CH4 emissions,â€ says Bert Weckhuysen, a professor at https://www.uu.nl/en (Utrecht University) in the Netherlands.
The urgency of the climate crisis and the increase in natural gas production accelerate the need for an efficient way to convert methane into liquid fuels and other commodity chemicals. Working to meet this need is the European Research Council-funded project ZeoMemRx (Greenhouse gases to valuable liquid chemicals: High-flux zeolite membrane-based reactor for the efficient conversion of CH4 and CO2).
â€œThe conversion of CH4 and CO2 are interconnected goals,â€ explains Weckhuysen, the principal investigator. â€œA promising strategy for accomplishing this dual conversion is to transform the two gases into easily transported liquid chemicals.â€
This approach is particularly attractive because such a conversion reduces the amount of emissions released into the atmosphere. Furthermore, it also produces commodity chemicals that can be used either as fuels or as precursors for many industrial processes. â€œUnfortunately, actually doing this transformation is easier said than done,â€ says Weckhuysen.

According to Weckhuysen, several major issues exist in the current approaches to CH4 and CO2 conversion, separation, and use. For example, converting CO2 into more valuable chemicals requires a dependable source of hydrogen. Thereâ€™s also the fact that CO2â€™s high thermodynamic stability makes it very difficult to transform it into other chemicals.
Then thereâ€™s the matter of CH4â€™s fast deactivation, not to mention that CH4 often only exists at wells located in very remote areas. This latter problem makes current gas-to-liquid technologies, such as conversion to syngas followed by upgrading via the Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) process, uneconomical.
These challenges require innovative approaches to designing more efficient and economical processes for converting CH4 and CO2 into high-value chemicals â€“ which is exactly what the ZeoMemRx project is attempting to do. â€œWe are proposing a high-flux zeolite membrane reactor capable of effectively converting a mixture of CH4 and CO2 into hydrocarbons and aromatics â€“ including benzene, a versatile platform chemical,â€ remarks Weckhuysen.
A key feature of the envisioned system is a highly oriented zeolite membrane with a tunable composition fabricated on a porous substrate. This will give the system the ability to shift the reaction equilibrium and decrease the contact time, resulting in a high catalytic performance.

section.sectionTitle: The right people, right skills and right goals
section.sectionBody:
Although still a work in progress, researchers have succeeded in preparing the highly oriented zeolite and related catalyst materials needed to activate CO2 and CH4. Theyâ€™ve also developed the first prototype membrane reactor system for initiating the reaction, which is now undergoing further assessment.
â€œEverything from the transfer of knowledge to the build-up of the new reactor system and the creation of new materials are the result of the teamwork and collaboration that have defined this project,â€ concludes Weckhuysen. â€œYou can have a great idea, but without the right people, the right skills, and the right goals, it will remain only that â€“ an idea.â€

article.keywords: ZeoMemRx, climate change, greenhouse gases, natural gas, liquid chemicals

article.title: Frontier chemistry: Helping to achieve a truly green and circular economy for Europe
article.teaser: The EU must use every tool in its arsenal to achieve its wide-reaching and ambitious climate goals, particularly the goal to be fully carbon-neutral by 2050. One of those tools is innovative chemistry research with a focus on catalysis â€“ the process of increasing the rate of a chemical reaction by adding a substance known as a â€˜catalystâ€™. In this CORDIS Results Pack, we highlight the efforts of 14 projects funded by the European Research Council (ERC) that work within this field and make substantial contributions to the development of greener and more sustainable industrial processes.

article.title: ColaboraciÃ³n euroafricana para mejorar la resiliencia de Ãfrica ante el cambio climÃ¡tico
article.teaser: Los retos relacionados con el cambio climÃ¡tico representan unas de las amenazas mundiales mÃ¡s urgentes de este milenio. Ãfrica y Europa trabajan conjuntamente para compartir y generar conocimientos, crear asociaciones y dirigir proyectos que prepararÃ¡n a Ãfrica ante dichos retos.

section.sectionBody: Ãfrica es particularmente vulnerable al cambio climÃ¡tico y muchas redes y organizaciones africanas trabajan arduamente en soluciones de mitigaciÃ³n del impacto en el continente. El proyecto https://www.afrialliance.org/ (AfriAlliance), financiado con fondos europeos, les ayuda a aunar fuerzas con las partes interesadas europeas para compartir conocimientos, fortalecer la capacidad y acelerar la innovaciÃ³n de forma general, a fin de que Ãfrica estÃ© mejor preparada para encarar los futuros retos sobre seguridad hÃ­drica y cambio climÃ¡tico.

section.sectionTitle: Trabajar juntos para un futuro mejor
section.sectionBody: Uta Wehn, coordinadora del proyecto, seÃ±ala: Â«El proyecto AfriAlliance ha puesto en marcha diez https://www.afrialliance.org/action-groups (grupos de acciÃ³n) basados en la demanda por todo Ãfrica, que reÃºnen a homÃ³logos africanos y europeos para que trabajen conjuntamente en busca de soluciones viables. El proyecto se centra en temas tan diversos como la recogida de agua para la agricultura, la gestiÃ³n de los recursos hÃ­dricos, la ciencia ciudadana y la administraciÃ³n del aguaÂ». El proyecto AfriAlliance ahora cuenta con una comunidad de mÃ¡s de quinientas entidades, las cuales se destacan en el https://www.afrialliance.org/knowledge-hub/afrialliance-stakeholder-map/afrialliance-stakeholder-map (mapa de las partes interesadas de AfriAlliance). Dichas entidades incluyen organizaciones sin Ã¡nimo de lucro, empresariales, acadÃ©micas y de financiaciÃ³n, grupos agrÃ­colas, juveniles y de mujeres, autoridades pÃºblicas y diversos proyectos y plataformas. Sensibilizar y fortalecer la cantidad de participantes tendrÃ¡ un papel fundamental para poder afrontar futuros retos.

AdemÃ¡s de unir a las personas, el proyecto AfriAlliance ofrece informaciÃ³n accesible a travÃ©s de su https://www.afrialliance.org/knowledge-hub (centro de conocimiento). Esta ventanilla Ãºnica proporciona https://www.afrialliance.org/knowledge-hub/afrialliance-policy-briefs (informes polÃ­ticos) y https://www.afrialliance.org/knowledge-hub/afrialliance-social-innovation-factsheets (fichas informativas sobre innovaciÃ³n social) elaborados por el proyecto, asÃ­ como https://www.afrialliance.org/knowledge-hub/water-and-climate-updates (actualizaciones relativas al clima y al agua) e https://www.afrialliance.org/knowledge-hub/scientific-papers-and-reports (informes y trabajos cientÃ­ficos) pertinentes.
El centro de conocimiento tambiÃ©n alberga informaciÃ³n sobre oportunidades de aprendizaje en lÃ­nea, tanto para el proyecto AfriAlliance como para otras instituciones. El prÃ³ximo curso masivo abierto en lÃ­nea del proyecto AfriAlliance se impartirÃ¡ en junio de 2020 y se centrarÃ¡ en la innovaciÃ³n social para los desafÃ­os climÃ¡ticos e hÃ­dricos en Ãfrica. Es posible consultar los prÃ³ximos https://afrialliance.org/events (eventos sobre el agua y el clima), las https://www.afrialliance.org/knowledge-hub/funding-opportunities (oportunidades de financiaciÃ³n), asÃ­ como las https://www.afrialliance.org/knowledge-hub/further-education-scholarships-and-career-opportunities (oportunidades profesionales, educativas y sobre becas).
El equipo ha desarrollado un mÃ©todo para recopilar y analizar datos hÃ­dricos y climÃ¡ticos. Wehn aÃ±ade: Â«El proyecto AfriAlliance ha creado la metodologÃ­a de colocaciÃ³n de un sensor triple para supervisiones y previsiones. Permite que los usuarios validen tres observaciones independientes sobre el agua y el clima (datos de estaciones terrestres convencionales, satelitales y de origen ciudadano), ademÃ¡s de clasificar su fiabilidadÂ». En el sitio web del proyecto, puede consultarse una http://afrialliance.itc.utwente.nl/triplesensor/ (demostraciÃ³n interactiva) y descargarse el http://ftp.itc.nl/pub/52n/AfriAlliance/ (Â«softwareÂ» y la documentaciÃ³n del conjunto de herramientas de demostraciÃ³n). El portal de geodatos del equipo ahora tiene mÃ¡s de 140Â entradas y metainformaciÃ³n sobre datos climÃ¡ticos y recursos hÃ­dricos africanos.

section.sectionTitle: Consolidar los pilares de la seguridad y la sostenibilidad
section.sectionBody:
Â«El proyecto AfriAlliance ha identificado y priorizado las necesidades de las organizaciones africanas de gestiÃ³n del agua en el contexto de diversos escenarios sobre el cambio climÃ¡tico. Evaluamos soluciones, actuales y nuevas, asÃ­ como los obstÃ¡culos que impiden su implementaciÃ³n. AfriAlliance ha desarrollado nuevas maneras de abordar las necesidades y las soluciones, incluso a travÃ©s de nuestros eventos sobre puentes de innovaciÃ³n y actividades promocionales. El prÃ³ximo paso es fortalecer un entorno propicio para la innovaciÃ³n en materia de agua en Ãfrica. Para ello, el equipo ha formulado principios rectores y recomendaciones a fin de proporcionar directrices para la polÃ­tica de innovaciÃ³n del sector hÃ­drico africanoÂ», informa Wehn. En el contexto de las mejores prÃ¡cticas actuales y las condiciones locales, las directrices permitirÃ¡n una aplicaciÃ³n, una adaptaciÃ³n y un diseÃ±o conjunto exitosos de las innovaciones en materia de agua y cambio climÃ¡tico en Ãfrica.
AdemÃ¡s de construir los pilares para las acciones especÃ­ficas, el proyecto AfriAlliance ha preparado planes de negocio para diversos resultados del proyecto, en aras de garantizar su sostenibilidad mÃ¡s allÃ¡ de la duraciÃ³n del proyecto. Este proyecto quinquenal estarÃ¡ en marcha durante otro aÃ±o, pero sus repercusiones seguirÃ¡n en aumento, lo que fortalecerÃ¡ la resiliencia de Ãfrica ante el cambio climÃ¡tico.

article.keywords: AfriAlliance, Ãfrica, clima, agua, agricultura, saneamiento, colocaciÃ³n de un sensor triple, previsiones, geodatos

article.title: InnovaciÃ³n en materia de agua para Ãfrica: soluciones sostenibles para la gestiÃ³n hidrolÃ³gica
article.teaser: En marzo de 2020, la ComisiÃ³n Europea y el alto representante de la UniÃ³n para Asuntos Exteriores y PolÃ­tica de Seguridad propuso la base de una nueva estrategia con Ãfrica. En la comunicaciÃ³n conjunta se establecen propuestas para intensificar la cooperaciÃ³n mediante asociaciones en cinco Ã¡mbitos clave, uno de los cuales es la transiciÃ³n ecolÃ³gica. Europa entablarÃ¡ conversaciones con socios africanos para desarrollar una nueva estrategia conjunta que deberÃ¡ refrendarse en la prÃ³xima Cumbre UniÃ³n Europeaâ€“UniÃ³n Africana. En este Results Pack de CORDIS se presentan algunos de los proyectos de investigaciÃ³n e innovaciÃ³n vanguardistas que abordan los desafÃ­os hÃ­dricos en Ãfrica, con vistas a proporcionar comentarios al respecto, asÃ­ como sobre otras iniciativas euroafricanas conjuntas.

article.title: Increasing power capacity
article.teaser: An EU-funded project has achieved a significant size reduction in saturated core FCL and has improved its performance envelope, thus creating new market opportunities.

section.sectionBody:
To satisfy societyâ€™s continuously increasing power consumption requires that we develop additional generation supply and network connectivity. Although with each power source or sub-network added to the electricity grid, its operational flexibility increases, at the same time it also magnifies the probability of uncontrollable short circuit fault currents that exceed network protection limits. These cascading fault currents disrupt supply, damage equipment and lead to severe power outages that can cost hundreds of millions of euros.
As a result, electricity network operators are looking for ways to increase power capacity by adding energy sources while maintaining grid resiliency. The challenge, however, is that conventional solutions such as grid segmentation and network upgrades usually cost between a few and hundreds of millions of euros. Furthermore, these solutions have a negative impact on power quality, stability and reliability â€“ essentially negating any benefit that they bring. For this reason, many electricity network operators are turning their attention to new Fault Current Limiting (FCL) alternative solutions.
â€˜FCL is a solution for increased capacity in electricity networks and for cost-effective connection of distributed generation and renewable resources,â€™ says Yoram Valent, CEO and Co-Founder of GridON Ltd and Coordinator of the EU-funded FCL Project.
Building a better FCL solution
GridON, a leading provider of FCL solutions, provides fault mitigation solutions for network operators, independent power producers and industrial customers. The companyâ€™s FCLs have been operating flawlessly in live networks since early 2013, and are considered reliable, easy to operate and maintain, and very effective in limiting numerous faults. These FCL solutions significantly reduce capital expenditure while avoiding labour and time-consuming upgrades and early retirement of fit-for-use equipment.
â€˜Our fault mitigation solutions enable increased power capacity and cost-effective connection of distributed generation and intermittent renewable energy sources,â€™ adds Valent. â€˜They also improve energy efficiency and network stability and reduce carbon emissions.â€™
However, the baseline FCL solution (at the beginning of the project) was not viable for some specific market segments. For example, medium-voltage distribution and industrial networks require a smaller and cheaper product. Through the EU-funded FCL project, GridON researchers were able to achieve a significant size reduction in the companyâ€™s saturated core FCL and improve its performance envelope. â€˜We successfully developed an improved saturated core FCL by adding a newly developed power-electronics switching system,â€™ explains Valent. â€˜This integrated novel architecture allowed for a reduction of the main FCL unitâ€™s footprint and costs, thus positioning it as a very attractive solution for distribution networks and industrial customers.â€™
Opening the door to new possibilities
The achieved results of the project open the possibility for wider market adoption of the FCL solution, as well as tapping applications that were not feasible or less attractive with the first-generation technology. â€˜The improved FCL enables simple, cost-effective connection of new generation sources to existing power grids,â€™ says Valent. â€˜Such new connections increase the generation capacity of dense urban areas and may offer reduced electricity cost, not to mention create new revenues for businesses with generation capability.â€™
Thanks to the cost-effective FCL developed in this project, industrial customers can now increase the power capacity of their plants. This directly enables cost savings in upgrading existing equipment, saves time in approving new connections of distributed generation and reduces the carbon footprint of the network.
Valent says GridON plans to further commercialise the power-electronics based FCL technology and to promote it with worldwide prospective customers and stakeholders.

article.keywords: FCL, GRIDON, electric grids, power consumption

project.teaser: Electricity networks are required to accommodate additional generation sources, which increase the exposure to fault currents; causing damages of billions of euros, and impacting millions of people. Utilities are forced to invest hundreds of millions in order to prevent...
project.title: Upgrading a commercially-available Fault Current Limiter to a more cost-effective device for enabling additional capacity and improving energy efficiency, by limiting destructive fault currents
